awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Carbon Nanotube Enabled High-Temperature Wireless Sensor System
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project will develop innovative sensors based on vertically aligned carbon nanotube (CNT) diode structures to increase the range and performance of wireless microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) sensors in high-temperature environments.  Currently, wireless sensors are limited by the need to protect the electronics from the sensor environment.  This research will develop sensor architectures that utilize CNT structures with non-linear electrical behavior to improve sensor performance under harsh conditions. This effort will develop nanostructured materials that survive extended lifetimes in high-temperature environments, and affordable fabrication approaches that integrate these structures into high-temperature MEMS.  The Phase 1 effort will investigate high-risk concepts including the performance limits of high-temperature CNT-based electronics in wireless sensing and the microfabrication techniques to integrate these structures onto a sensor device.  A majority of the work proposed focuses on fabrication validation and experimental verification, where the remainder will include modeling and design of the CNT-based sensors.  If successful, this research will enable new in-situ health monitoring capabilities at high-temperature.  This technology is highly scalable and will provide these benefits at low capital cost and low ongoing cost. 

The broader impact/commercial benefit of this project lies in the extension of extension of wireless MEMS sensor technology to higher temperature operation and the cost savings and energy savings that can be gained through the resulting increase in industrial process efficiency.  Because the target market is high-temperature industrial process and system monitoring, such as in the energy, oil and gas, and turbomachinery industries, these sensors would permit savings in terms of production time, reduced downtime, and the energy required to maintain process and equipment temperature.  Within certain situations, this sensor technology would enable wireless point measurements that are currently not feasible or affordable.  Relevant and affordable monitoring solutions for low- to medium-cost industrial equipment will be beneficial to rural facilities and small-scale manufacturers who tend to use older technology, maintain small capital budgets, and operate under tight cash-flow restrictions. The broader impacts of this technology to science and education include advancing existing micro- and nano-sensor technology and funding for continued research and education in RF sensors, electronic packaging, and nanostructured materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this Phase I effort was to demonstrate the feasibility of ceramic sensors with integrated carbon nanotube electronics to realize wireless sensor tags suitable for high-temperature environments.  Many wireless sensor installations operate in low-temperature environments, within the limits of the electronics and batteries. However, some industries such as chemical processing, power generation, aerospace, and material manufacturing, would benefit from high-temperature wireless monitoring. There is currently a significant lack of wireless sensor technologies that can operate at the elevated temperatures seen in these industries. While many of the transducers themselves, such as thermocouples, oxygen sensors, and some strain gages, can survive elevated temperatures, the electronics required to operate wirelessly, as well as the need for onboard power storage, limit the useful temperature range. As a result, wireless sensor systems often connect the high temperature transducer to a separate electronics box that is safely removed, thus reducing the benefit of wireless sensing

The objectives of the Phase I effort  were to demonstrate high-temperature non-linear carbon nanotube diode performance, to demonstrate fabrication processes to assemble and integrate high-temperature diodes into ceramic sensor tags, and to define requirements for the transceiver required to read those sensor tags. During the Phase I effort, a series of tasks were performed to achieve the program objectives. These tasks included growing carbon nanotube structures on silicon and ceramic substrates, vacuum packaging those nanotubes into field emission diode structures, and testing those structures at various temperature levels. In addition, wireless sensor tags with integrated diodes were assembled and tested, and a wireless transceiver was designed to interrogate these tags.

The technical accomplishments of the Phase I effort included fabricating and packaging CNT-based diodes, as well as operation of those diodes at room temperature and elevated temperatures. The effort also operated a diode based sensor tag within a stainless steel structure as a demonstration of high-temperature sensor applications. Through these activities, the operation of a carbon nanotube based passive wireless appears to be feasible for high temperature monitoring applications. Development risks increase as temperature is increased due to material performance and attachment mechanisms, but much of the risk is mitigated by having high temperature active components available. In terms of broader impact, these technical accomplishments included the development of processes for nanotube growth on ceramic substrates and for the vacuum packaging of CNT-based electronics. These processes can find application in other high-temperature electronic devices.

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2015
Modified by: Michael S Kranz
